q1.question: Which of the following statements regarding system calls are true (choose all that apply)?

responses.block: When a system call occurs, the process is blocked until the kernel returns a result.
responses.cheap: Because system calls are handled by the kernel, they are generally fast and efficient when compared to normal function calls.
responses.context: A system call always leads to a context switch from one process to another.
responses.modes: A system call always leads to a transition from user mode to kernel mode.
responses.trap: One way to implement system calls is to have a user application perform a trap that is caught by the CPU.
responses.table: The code to handle each system call is stored in the CPU's trap table.
responses.signal: Each process sets up its trap table by using the signal system call.

q2.question: Which of the following statements regarding signals are true (choose all that apply)?

responses.ignored: Any signal can be ignored by a user process.
responses.interrupt: When a signal is delivered to a process, the process is interrupted and then runs the corresponding handler before returning to where it was interrupted.
responses.signal: Applications can send a signal to another process by using the signal system call.
responses.kill: Applications can send a signal to another process by using the kill system call.
responses.syscall: Signals can interrupt system calls such as read.
responses.pause: To pause another process, you can send it the SIGPAUSE signal.
responses.cont: To unpause another process, you can send it the SIGCONT signal.

q3.question: Which of the following statements regarding process states are true (choose all that apply)?

responses.new: A new process is automatically placed in the running state when it is created.
responses.blocked: A process can go from blocked to running when a system call completes.
responses.running: A process can go from running to blocked when a system call is initiated.
responses.ready: A process can go from blocked to ready when a system call completes.
responses.timeslice: A process can go from running to ready when its timeslice is up.
responses.context: A context switch usually occurs when a process goes from running to ready.
responses.terminated: A process can only be terminated when it is in the waiting state.
